qas.question: Since when has all filming and photography in the Rotunda for the Charters of Freedom been banned?
For how long has the National Archives prohibited flash photography?
What is an aspect of a visit to the Rotunda for the Charters of Freedom?
What has made the no photography rule hard to enforce in the Rotunda for the Charters of Freedom?

answers.text: advent of cameras with automatic flashes

qas.question: How long have there been no lines to see individual documents?
Since what date have visitors been allowed into the Rotunda?
What year did the National Archives open to the public?
How long ago were the Charters of Freedom found?
Was it difficult to enforce the ban on the public entering the Rotunda before February 25, 2010?

context: Once inside the Rotunda for the Charters of Freedom, there are <a2_0>no lines<a2_0/> to see the individual documents and visitors are allowed to walk from document to document as they wish. For <a1_0><b4_0>over <b7_0>30 years<b7_0/><b4_0/><a1_0/> the National Archives have forbidden flash photography but the <a3_0>advent of cameras with automatic flashes<a3_0/> have made the rules increasingly <b8_0>difficult to enforce<b8_0/>. As a result, all filming, photographing, and videotaping by the public in the exhibition areas has been prohibited since <a0_0><b5_0>February 25, <b6_0>2010<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>.
